review.title: Crowdsourcing Pareto-Optimal Object Finding by Pairwise Comparisons
review.abstract: This is the first study on crowdsourcing Pareto-optimal object finding, which has applications in public opinion collection, group decision making, and information exploration. Departing from prior studies on crowdsourcing skyline and ranking queries, it considers the case where objects do not have explicit attributes and preference relations on objects are strict partial orders. The partial orders are derived by aggregating crowdsourcers' responses to pairwise comparison questions. The goal is to find all Pareto-optimal objects by the fewest possible questions. It employs an iterative question-selection framework. Guided by the principle of eagerly identifying non-Pareto optimal objects, the framework only chooses candidate questions which must satisfy three conditions. This design is both sufficient and efficient, as it is proven to find a short terminal question sequence. The framework is further steered by two ideas---macro-ordering and micro-ordering. By different micro-ordering heuristics, the framework is instantiated into several algorithms with varying power in pruning questions. Experiment results using both real crowdsourcing marketplace and simulations exhibited not only orders of magnitude reductions in questions when compared with a brute-force approach, but also close-to-optimal performance from the most efficient instantiation.

metadata.title: Crowdsourcing Pareto-Optimal Object Finding by Pairwise Comparisons

sections.text: The question we are asking ourselves is whether and how to consider such a task - crowdsourcing Pareto-optimal object finding. An object x that has a set of objects O and a set of criteria C for comparing the objects is better than a Pareto optimum if and only if x is not dominated by another object, i.e., an object y that dominates y-x. An object y dominates x (denoted y-x) if x is not better than a criterion and a criterion is better than x, i.e., an object y that dominates y-x (denoted y y-x) if x is not better than a criterion and a criterion at least one criterion, i.e., an object y that dominates y-x (denoted y y-x), if x is not better than a criterion and a criterion at least one criterion, i.e.,

sections.heading: II. RELATED WORK
sections.text: This is the first work on crowdsourcing Pareto-optimal object finding. In addition, there are several recent studies on the use of crowdsourcing to arrange and answer objects by asking human workers to rate small subsets of objects. Davidson et al. [13] evaluates top-k and group comparisons by asking the crowd to answer questions (whether two objects belong to the same group) and to ask questions (such as the arrangement of two objects). Lofi et al. [8] answers skyline questions by asking the crowd to provide missing attributes. I summarize the similarities and differences between these studies and our work.

sections.heading: III. GENERAL FRAMEWORK
sections.text: The key to finding such objects is to maintain the preference relationships, i.e., the strict partial definitions of individual criteria. Towards this end, the most basic approach is to perform a pair-wise comparison - given a pair of objects x and y and a criterion c, to determine whether one is better than the other (i.e., (x, y). The problem of crowdsourcing Pareto-optimal object finding is thus essentially crowdsourcing pair-wise comparisons. Each comparison task between x and y is presented by criterion c to the mass as a question q (denoted x?).The result of the question (denoted rlt) is aggregated by the answers of the mass.

sections.heading: A. Question Selection
sections.text: The goal is to find a sequence as short as possible. (Figs. 3 and Alg.1 show that the frame is an iterative procedure of object division based on question results. • It can also be considered a process of moving objects from O? to O · and O. "Once an object is controlled by another object, it cannot be moved again. In relation to this process, we make two important observations, as follows. • In order not to declare an object x as Pareto-optimal, it is sufficient to know that x is controlled by another object. It immediately follows that we do not really care about the dominance relationship between objects in O and can therefore skip the comparisons between such objects. Once we know x, it will be dominated by another object, it cannot be pareto-optimal and will move directly to O x.

sections.heading: V. EXPERIMENTS AND CASE STUDIES
sections.text: We designed and conducted experiments to compare the efficiency of different instances of the general framework under different problem sizes through simulations on a large dataset. We also investigated two case studies using a set of human judges and a true crowdsourcing marketplace.

sections.heading: A. Efficiency and Scalability Test by Simulation
sections.text: This year it has come to the point that it has never come as far as this year.

sections.heading: B. Case Studies
sections.text: 1) Case Study 1: Gathering opinions from a small group of people (see Example 1): We asked a small number of students at our institution to compare 10 US cities on general weather, job opportunities and cost of living. 135 possible pairs of comparison questions were divided into 15 questionnaires, each of which contained 9 questions on one criterion. Fig.9 shows such a question. We required answers from 10 people for each form. Some people skipped various questions posed by the "unsafe" option in Fig.9. Finally, we collected at least 6 answers to each question. The results were derived by defining an equal number of questions (see Equation (1). Table V shows the number of questions allowed by different methods in this case study Fig.9, an average of over 30 executions. While the performance gap between different methods is much smaller than in Sec.V-A, we find that it is due to the very small amount of objects.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: This paper is the first study on how to crowd-source Pareto-optimal objects when objects do not have explicit attributes and preference relationships are strict sub-orders; the sub-orders are determined by asking the crowd pairs of comparison questions; an iterative questionnaire selection system is introduced, which is instantiated into different methods by using the ideas of candidate questions, macro and micro-ordering; experiments have been conducted with simulations of large object sets and case studies using both human judges and a real crowdsourcing marketplace; the results not only revealed orders of magnitude of issues compared to a brute force approach, but also near-optimal performance compared to the most efficient method.

It is known that people are more comfortable and confident with comparing objects than directly scoring them, since it is easier, faster, and less error-prone [9].

This is not only a direct effect of using pairwise comparisons instead of numeric scores or explicit attribute values, but also a reflection of the psychological nature of human’s preferences [10], [2], since it is not always natural to enforce a total or bucket order.

Besides [11], there were multiple studies on ranking objects by pairwise comparisons, which date back to decades ago as aggregating the preferences of multiple agents has always been a fundamental problem in social choice and welfare [14].
The more recent studies can be categorized into three types: 1) Approaches such as [15], [16], [17] predict users’ object ranking by completing a user-object scoring matrix.

Their predications take into account users’ similarities in pairwise comparisons, resembling collaborative filtering [18].

metadata.abstractText: This is the first study on crowdsourcing Paretooptimal object finding, which has applications in public opinion collection, group decision making, and information exploration. Departing from prior studies on crowdsourcing skyline and ranking queries, it considers the case where objects do not have explicit attributes and preference relations on objects are strict partial orders. The partial orders are derived by aggregating crowdsourcers’ responses to pairwise comparison questions. The goal is to find all Pareto-optimal objects by the fewest possible questions. It employs an iterative question-selection framework. Guided by the principle of eagerly identifying non-Pareto optimal objects, the framework only chooses candidate questions which must satisfy three conditions. This design is both sufficient and efficient, as it is proven to find a short terminal question sequence. The framework is further steered by two ideas—macro-ordering and micro-ordering. By different micro-ordering heuristics, the framework is instantiated into several algorithms with varying power in pruning questions. Experiment results using both real crowdsourcing marketplace and simulations exhibited not only orders of magnitude reductions in questions when compared with a brute-force approach, but also close-to-optimal performance from the most efficient instantiation.
